Initial Thoughts: Just completed Edios's "Tomb Raider". I Finished in just under 12 hours; I'm slow at completing games, keep that in mind. This is one of those games that‚Äôs been sitting in my Steam library for years, always meant to play it, just never got around to it. After finally giving it a go, I wasn‚Äôt sure if I was vibing with it at first, but about halfway through, I started to enjoy it. In fact, I‚Äôm now considering picking up the sequels to see the series through.

Story: Without giving too much away, the storyline is a great reimagining of how Lara Croft becomes the iconic adventurer we know and love. That said, it leans heavily on a few annoying clich√©s. There are moments in cutscenes where Lara clearly has better tools available but chooses the worst tool for the job instead; like using her fucking bow over the fully automatic rifle she was just using moments ago before the cutscene, purely of course to put her in a situation that pushes the plot forward. These are cheap narrative shortcuts that could‚Äôve been handled way better imo.

Characters: The supporting cast is full of life and easy to connect with, and the developers deserve credit for that. However, the game throws a lot of chicky melodrama in your face too many times. While I appreciate their attempt to show Lara‚Äôs transformation from a young, innocent girl into a battle-hardened kickass explorer, a lot of the BS could‚Äôve been trimmed without hurting her development or the pacing.

Gameplay & Mechanics: It‚Äôs a pretty standard third-person action-adventure. Oddly, there‚Äôs no dedicated crouch mechanic, and cover can feel pretty unreliable at times. You can jump and climb around freely; sometimes almost too freely, which can look a little goofy but also adds to the fun. My biggest complaint is the constant quick-time events. They interrupt the flow far too often, and the feedback during them isn‚Äôt satisfying at all. On the positive side, platforming is smooth, controls are tight, and the puzzles are straightforward but enjoyable.

Graphics: Visually, the game holds up well for its time, this game is 12 years old as of writing this. The island setting is gorgeous, the weather effects are immersive, and the water physics look great even by today‚Äôs standards. Despite showing its age in some areas, the presentation overall does an excellent job of pulling you into the world.

Final Thoughts: Tomb Raider is a strong reboot of a phenomenal franchise that will leave you wanting more adventure after the pistol smoke clears.

One of the classics / greats. I remember playing this on X360 and thinking it was the best graphics I'd ever seen. I later played it on a decent PC rig at higher settings but couldn't quite manage Ultra. It's been years since then and who would've thought that I'd be replaying it now on Ultra on.. Mac? Yeah, as it turns out Mac's can game now.

Honestly this game is so much better than I remember it being, and I have very fond memories of it. It holds up incredibly well, better than a lot of modern games actually. I love how the world is somewhat open and feels real and well realised, but it always steers you back to a linear path. I found the sequel too open and trying to do too much but it's been a long time since I tried it so I will probably give it another go after I'm done with this.

Graphically it is gorgeous. I honestly can't get over how good it looks maxed out. Maybe it's the modern Macbook screens pushing an OLED-esque quality but holy damn, it is simply stunning. The detail in environments, the saturation, the foliage, the weather effects, the clarity, the ambient effects, the detail on Lara's face... It looks better in gameplay than cutscenes fr fr. 

Gameplay is actually fantastic too, and way better than I remember. Gunplay is satisfying and puzzles are fun. Climbing is good, although I can get a little impatient with Lara's speed! I'm playing on Hard and it's a really satisfying challenge, makes it feel a lot more immersive than the regular difficulty.

There are so many awesome details that really do make this game feel so ahead of its time. I love the way Lara feels to control, her movements are very fluid and I love how she organically adjusts here posture based on context and moves into cover without being glued in. 

Other details like the way she reaches out to touch walls as you pass by and, a personal favourite of mine, her attention gets caught by the environment, such as rats: she will watch them as they run by, amused in a realistic, human way. It makes her and the game world feel alive, connected and natural. Super immersive. Devs really poured passion into this one and you can see and feel it.

So yeah, whether you haven't played this for a while or are yet to give it a go, I can sincerely recommend it. It's a classic and if you run it maxed out, it has barely aged a day.

First, there are fun parts to the game, the graphics look good(except Lara looks different from the original games), and the audio is good(except some really repetitive sections)  There are many problems with this game, and it's not just that the game is really buggy(game breaking in some sections.) As I said there were fun parts, but the annoying things outweighed the fun.  Aside from that, it was mostly very easy, and I played on the [i]Hard Setting[/i].

Things I had an issue with:

- Automatic hints, and the NPCs will give you the solution almost immediately,
  before you've even had a chance to look around and figure things out
- Very few challenging puzzles;  most are very, very simple(not really puzzles),
   and just take common sense to solve.  Even so, you'll have NPCs telling you how
   to solve it anyway.
- Lara automatically crouches/changes stance when enemies are near, giving a player
   a visual warning that enemies are nearby.  Just another example of dumbing down a game
- Too Much Ammo Available - Even on Hard I rarely ever had any less than full ammo 
  on all ammo types.  Most of the time I couldn't pick up ammo because I was already full.  Again,
  this was on the [i]Hard[/i] setting.
- Zoom stops working in some area/times
- Geometry issues in DLC Tomb with Crashed plane(req. leaving/restarting)
- using Torch happens automatically, swithes to your handgun and you have to aim first to 
   be able to change back to your chosen weapon.
- awkward controls that change based on your view
- very restrictive view angles in some areas;  sometimes you can't look anywhere at all,
   which adds to the feeling of the game being overly linear.
- when dodging/countering, the camera always turns away from the view you're facing,
   or pushes you around corners, leaving you exposed to enemies;  the camera will often
   place your view away from the enemy; again leaving you exposed.
- controls are all over the place, and work against you.
-  Quick Time Events(QTE) that look like cutscenes, until you start seeing button cues pop
    up on the screen, and after you've leaned back to watch the cutscene.
- no warning when QTEs are over
-  Many QTE's lead to actions which change controls in awkward ways;  running toward
    the camera, away from the camera, at oblique angles,etc., so you have to figure out
    the ever changing controls on the fly.
 - very clunky controls from time to time
- the game feels very linear at times, forcing a player into a certain direction
- useable surfaces splashed with white paint, rather than letting the player
  explore and find out what they can climb
- Crosshair shows a clean shot, but hits background surfaces when you shoot;
    Blocking Geometry isn't taken into account when zooming in.
- aiming near corners automatically puts you most of the way around the corner
  allowing enemies to easily hit you
- getting fired on and/or hit when an enemy has no line of sight
- Weapons shoulder placement always changing for weapons(should remain till player toggles it)
- DLC Tombs show the same video every time you clear a hidden tomb; Lara opening a generic treasure 
  chest which doesn't show any particular item.  Clearing the DLC Tombs isn't rewarding at all, except the
  feeling of accomplishment from figuring out the puzzles(a few of them at least.)
- Dynamite  sometimes moves through walls and barriers, or under the floor.
- jumping and aiming stopped working on the Ritual Battle intermittently.
- Can't shoot Mathius at the Ritual Battle until the game wants you to;  the crosshair blanks out.
- I hit the Stormguard Boss, on Ritual Battle, from behind, and, somehow, 
  he picks me up by the neck?!

  most maps have no spawns, and it makes it hard to get some achievements.  So you have to
  start the game from the beginning to try for some achievements;  this requires regaining the
  skills you earned in the first playthrough.
